question: I think I'll take some meatloaf. No, I think I'll have some fish. No, no... fish doesn't fill you up. Meatloaf. He closes the menu.
answer: What do you think, 'Sally's pride' in the second? Get me a Bloody Mary.

question: What number is Sally's Pride?
answer: Six. No, I don't like to eat until the third race. Waiter walks off.

question: Six... six... six... six. I'm thinking one. Whose one?
answer: Mr. Motor.

question: Then that's it, I'm going with one.
answer: Tilley, this is insane. You're picking horses because you think you're clairvoyant or something.

question: Sam, I'm not doing too well by checking the stats, so why not. I put my hand to my forehead, I see a one -- Mr. Motor in the second... twenty bucks. They both look toward the track, the horses race to the finish line. Number nine streaks across the finish line.
answer: Hallihan's Daughter.

question: I got it... I got it... He picks up the racing form. Three to one... hundred and sixty smackers. Hand to the forehead! Hand to the forehead!
answer: You're not exactly talking about a long shot. Mr. Motor, for instance, is coming off at 50 to 1. Tilley taps his forehead, with his eyes closed.

question: Third race, I see a six... I see a three. I don't think the verdict's in on that one yet. Tilley stands up and is going through his money and race tickets. Wing paid a hundred on number five, he loses, I got hundred and forty... next race I'll lay down the bet. What you taking in this race?
answer: Thrifty's Delight -- number four -- 20 bucks.

question: You take Thrifty's Delight -- 20 bucks, I got 20 on Mr. Motor, Wing's got a hundred on Night Fire. What's the odds on Night Fire?
answer: Twenty to one.

question: I don't see Night Fire winning. Fuck it, I'm not gonna even place the bet... I just made a hundred bucks.
answer: What are you, crazy? What happens if he wins?

question: I tell you something, she's getting on my nerves.
answer: Who, Nora?

question: Yeah, yeah... who else is it gonna be... 'who, Nora"!... who else is there? The whole idea of being with a girl on consecutive nights is new to me. It's one thing when they're with you for a night, but when they live with ya, it's stretching the point. They got a lot of things they bring with them... you go to the bathroom you see 'things' you never saw before.
answer: So, what's the todo?

question: Well, they move your stuff around and it's not where it used to be... I'm not used to that.
answer: You mean all this time you've never lived with a girl?

question: What?! Did we just meet? How long we been partners? No, I've never lived with a girl!
answer: Boy, oh boy! Did you wake up on the wrong side of the bed today?

question: Yes, I did. I came in last night, she was sleeping on my side of the bed. In my life I never got out of bed on the left side... in my life, never from the left. I got close once up in the Catskills. I met this girl, Dorian. For a week we were together, but it wasn't the same because she always went to her room to change and do all that stuff. She didn't have things in my room. All this 'cos I'm trying to get even with some guy. You know what? I think I got to see her and put an end to this. CUT TO:
answer: Yes. Bill! BB turns towards Nora. Nora waves to him, happily, with a twinkle in her eye. BB feels conspicuous -- people are looking at him. He gives a little wave.

question: Yeah. CUT TO:
answer: I'm glad you stopped by. This is a real surprise.

question: Listen, I got a problem.
answer: Oh. How can I help?

question: Um... er... Well, the problem is... like... is like... eh, you know... you're the problem.
answer: Really. How so?

question: There's things that are bothering me.
answer: Like what?

question: You know... things.
answer: Things?

question: You know, like things that come up... stuff... like... you know, annoyances.
answer: Annoyances?

question: Hard to explain... very hard.
answer: Well, try.

question: As an example... I came home last night, I get undressed, and I realize you're sleeping on my side of the bed. I've always slept on that side... it's something I've always done.
answer: Then why didn't you just nudge me a bit and tell me to go and sleep on the other side?

question: I didn't want to wake you up... I thought you might think it was kind of stupid or something.
answer: Well, that's easily changed.

question: But there are other things... bigger things. But I realize just talking about it, they all sound petty and silly.
answer: Listen, if you think all of this is going too fast, maybe I should move out. Is that what you want, Bill? BB looks around, very uncomfortable, and he shrugs. I really care for you, but if you think it's best. I don't want to make you unhappy. After a long beat.

question: I don't think we've got to take drastic action. Nora smiles. Thought I'd come by and get things off my chest... talk it out. Listen, I'm going over to Pimlico... catch the seventh race... wanna come?
answer: I can't get away from work.

question: Very nice!
answer: That was your horse, Wing?

question: Yeah... Southern Belle. You oughta know, you bet her for me.
answer: Of course. Wing goes to look at form.

question: I'm gonna go with the favorite in this one -- Fordnee Lane. I tell you what, I won sixteen plus on the other race, from those winnings you can bet me eight hundred.
answer: Eight hundred?

question: Yeah... I wanna bet eight hundred on Fordnee Lane.
answer: Fordnee lane -- eight hundred. Sam is looking at Tilley knowing that he's really in a jam. Eight hundred.

question: Waiter, can you get me a cup of coffee? Tilley looks over to Sam, with panic on his face. Wing turns back to Tilley and Sam. You guys want anything else?
answer: Er... hum... er... hey, Wing... I tell you, I got a problem.

question: What is it?
answer: It's the eight hundred on Fordnee Lane. I haven't got it.

question: No, you got it wrong. You take it from the sixteen plus I won... the eight hundred.
answer: I haven't got the winnings.

question: What do ya mean, you don't have my winnings?
answer: Wing, it was the craziest thing... I didn't want to mention it earlier because it was so nuts... it was the craziest thing.

question: What?
answer: I don't know how to even tell you this without being embarrassed for myself. It was an accident... it's like one of those things out of the blue... it's crazy... you can't explain it... it happens.

question: It happens... I don't know how... I don't know how to explain. It's too crazy, I swear to God, Wing.
answer: Wait a minute... you're telling me that I didn't win the last race?

question: You won, Wing... you won, it's just that you're not getting any money... it was a fluke. I swear, I don't know how it could have happened. A ten-year-old couldn't have made the mistake I made... I don't know, I swear.
answer: What the fuck is he talking about?

question: If there was some way I could make it up, believe me, I would, because you know where I stand. There's a beat while Wing just looks at Tilley. You know where I stand, Wing. If there was any way, believe me, I'd make it up. I'd give you thirty percent of what you didn't get because it was a fluke... I'm willing to make some kind of retribution.
answer: You just pocketed the God damned money... you just took my money and slipped it into your God damned pocket, didn't you?

question: No. I'd split fifty-fifty with you, that's how badly I feel under the circumstances.
answer: You get this straight, you son of a bitch, you owe me sixteen plus... I want sixteen plus.

question: Am I trying to shirk my responsibility? That's not the way I see it... it was a fluke, a crazy thing that happened, but I stand behind my honor on this... put it on my tab.
answer: What the hell is wrong with him? What the hell is wrong with him? He's stealing money from me... what the hell is wrong with him? Can you tell me?

question: It's like some guy trying to sell me life insurance. You think I'm gonna take some money out of my pocket to give to some jerk so that somebody can take it when I'm dead? No, Sam, you gotta live for today. I'm gonna live as good as I can every day. You know what I'm saying? As Sam and Tilley walk towards Tilley's Cadillac, BB and Moe are walking to BB's Cadillac parked close to Tilley's car. They see each other. Hey, Mr. Marengay went to the track!
answer: Did you bother to bet, or did you just hand your money to the tellers?

question: The sarcasm's killing me. I thought you were looking to get even.
answer: Who's your accountant, mister, 'cos I think you're down in the debit side.

question: Who's stuck with my wife. You or me? He laughs.
answer: You want me to believe that you were setting me up with your wife as some kind of decoy?

question: Decoy is the word! There's a long beat as the two guys eye one another. Then, almost in a soft apologetic manner, BB speaks.
answer: Okay then, you win. BB gets into his car.

question: This is good, Stan... nice work. Stanley nods. Fossey says it should go down very well with the city council. Could help us appropriate more funds. This goes a long way to establish our credibility in what we're trying to do. We hear a LOUD, SAWING noise and HAMMERING echoing through the warehouse throughout this scene.
answer: There's a lot more where this came from.

question: You know what I think you should do now. Why don't you pull some files... some files that were completed, others that went unsold, and I'll have somebody run it down, talk to the customers and get some statements.
answer: Pulling files is another thing. That might not be easy.

question: To sneak a few here and there when you can.
answer: I'll see.

question: What does that mean, Mr. Gable?
answer: You know what I do, Alan? I pick certain houses that are strategically located, we put up the aluminum siding, and for every referral, for every person who sees this quality job that we do... sees how beautiful it is... I give you two hundred dollars.

question: Two hundred dollars?
answer: That's right. God knows how many homes we could sell by people passing this house. It's perfectly placed for that. Alan, this is how confident I feel that this house will drum up business for me. He peels off four hundred dollars and hands the money to Shubner. Four hundred dollars... I'm giving you commission on two house referrals before I put a panel on the side of your house... that's how confident I feel.

question: You think that many people are going to...
answer: I'm certain of it. I'm not giving away four hundred dollars for my health... I'm a businessman, and I'm a good businessman. This is good business for me. I'm giving it away 'cos I believe in this house, believe that it will refer me to other jobs which means money in my pocket, which means money in your pocket.

question: I finally got hold of May... she was over your sister's.
answer: Oh, I forgot.

question: She'll be down here shortly.
answer: BB, I don't have any insurance. If I die, May's got nothing... nothing... nothing for Leonard. The only money I've got is in my pocket. That's all I got.

question: Just take it easy, Moe... rest.
answer: Did they sign? Did they sign?

question: Don't worry about it now.
answer: Goddamn it, BB! Did you sign them?

question: Don't worry... don't worry. I'll take care of it tomorrow.
answer: Goddamn, my chest hurts. I always taught you, BB, never walk out of a place without a signed contract. Somebody's word ain't spit.

question: They'll sign, Moe. Don't worry, they'll sign. This is kind of new to me, but I thought I better call and tell you I'm gonna be late... maybe two or three. I never had anyone there to call before, but I thought I should call, you know.
answer: Why? Do you think you have some obligation?

question: I dunno... I thought I'd better call, that's all.
answer: Well, I'm glad you did.

question: I don't know what's gonna happen to Moe.
answer: Well, I hope he's okay. I'll see you when you get in. She gives BB a kiss on the phone.

question: No way! He's a pig! He always eats more than anyone else. Why should I pay for his food?
answer: What're you talking about? Today I happened to have eggs and flapjacks, some cantalope, some juice and then another juice.

question: Like an animal! Like an animal!
answer: But yesterday, what did I have?

question: No. Through the diner window we see Nora's car pull up and park outside the diner.
answer: Then what did you have?

question: Guess.
answer: What is this, a quiz show? We don't know what you had. What did you have?

question: I had very little.
answer: Very little!! You eat like an animal! It couldn't have been very little.

question: Was not long ago you never would have seen a woman in here.
answer: You don't have to tell me. How many nights did you drop me off and come up here all the time?

question: I know. I was just trying to be congenial... you know, start a conversation off, on a nice kind of light level, you know. So, what's the scoop, Nora?
answer: Well you know, I think we really should get divorced.

question: Makes sense. You want some more coffee?
answer: Yeah, I'll have some.

question: Florence, some coffee here. It's for the best. You know, we were kind of fooling ourselves, weren't we?
answer: Yes, it went wrong somewhere along the line -- I don't know where though.

question: Yes, something went wrong... I don't know. Florence walks over and pours coffee for Tilley and Nora, then walks away. So you like this guy?
answer: Yeah, I like him.

question: All in all I guess it'll all work out for the best.
answer: I'm glad you feel that way.

question: Yeah, can you figure it out? A guy bangs into my car, thinks I did him in, tries to get even with me by stealing my wife, you two people fall in love... can you figure that out?
answer: What?

question: You telling me you didn't know this was the guy?
answer: This was that guy?

question: Yeah, I told you I ran into another tin man.
answer: He didn't tell me he was a tin man... he told me he sold baby pictures.

question: It's your life. All I know is this guy has a bent weather vane.
answer: Oh, God! Not another tin man. CUT TO:

question: Beeb, why don't you let Stanley work with you. I'm off to Florida at the end of the week for some sun and fun. Let Stanley work with you, and when I get back, we'll see how Moe's doing.
answer: I don't know. To be honest with you, I think I'd rather work alone ... he's too green. Is he a pain in the ass?

question: No. He don't talk much; he's a good listener, so he can't really get on your nerves. He's a lousy pool player and he can't play cards for shit, but...
answer: So what good is he?

question: Studious type... takes a lot of notes.
answer: If this is a sales pitch, I think you got to work a little harder 'cos I don't think you've got good product. CUT TO: What are you, crazy?! Nora drives the car forward and then backwards again almost running BB down. She rolls down the window so that she can yell.

question: Yes, sir... yes, sir!
answer: Take a look at this crap.

question: IRS? They're not gonna leave me alone!
answer: Home Improvement Commission. With those words there's a genuine moment of concern from all of the tin men -- even Mouse stops singing. Tilley picks up the envelope and pulls out the letter.

question: We've got to appear?
answer: I think that's the gist of what they're saying. Gil looks over Tilley's shoulder at the letter. Mouse comes over.

question: Can't we just ignore it? How do they know we got the letter.
answer: It's certified.

question: What do you think, Sam?
answer: I dunno... I don't know what they've got.

question: Not tonight, Ruthie, my dancing shoes are on holiday. I'm more than sure. Ruthie moves off. BB takes a shot of whiskey and downs it, and then drinks some beer.
answer: Who was the best you ever saw?

question: Best I ever saw? Best tin man I ever saw? He holds up his shot glass towards the bartender, and the bartender fills it up. Harry Apel... Dandy Flynn... those guys had good lines, but they burned themselves out too fast. Best? Moe's the best... the best there ever was. If he's in the door, he's got a sale. The best closer ever.
answer: What's some of the hustles he used to pull? BB downs another shot glass of whisky.

question: God damn Nora... God damn Nora! I'm trying to adjust... I'm putting up with things I never put up with in my life. I mean, give me a break... give me a break, woman. Stanely wants to get back to the topic of best tin man.
answer: So, what are a couple of things you and Moe have done?

question: It was getting to be real pleasant ... figure that. More than pleasant. To hell with her!
answer: How come Moe's so good? Why do you think, huh?

question: They got no right. You know what I'm saying, Sam? They've got no right. Tilley takes a drink from a pint of whisky he has open.
answer: They've got nothing concrete against us, because if it's just hearsay stuff, it's neither here nor there.

question: Where's my car? What happened to my car?
answer: It's better I drop you off.

question: Yeah, it's better. CUT TO:
answer: He ain't here. He gets out of the car and looks around the street some more. He stumbles up to a couple of parked cars, look- ing for Nora's car. He falls into some trash cans in front of the house. CUT TO:

question: I knew I could smell a rat! The son of a bitch is coming for me... the son of a bitch never wants to leave me alone! Tilley walks over to the night table, opens the drawer and pulls out a revolver. CUT TO: You want to rob my God damn house? I'm gonna make it easy for you. Come and rob Tilley... come on... take everything he's got. CUT TO:
answer: Hel... Before he can finish the word "Hello," Tilley hits him hard in the head with the butt of the gun. BB falls to the ground unconscious. CUT TO:

question: You're a sick man! You smash my car, you steal my wife, and now you come to rob me! You're one demented human being. BB tries to focus on Tilley. I'm going to call the police and send you to jail... but I'm going to humiliate you first. Tilley throws an egg at BB and hits him in the head. BB is groggy and confused and still drunk.
answer: What're you doing?

question: What do ya want to break into my house for? This ain't the fucking Rockefeller mansion! There ain't thirty-eight television sets here. They ain't saying 'Nelson, I think we've had a break-in... count the sets to see how many we've got left.' There ain't tons of jewelry hanging out of drawers... it ain't like I don't know which watch to put on, I got so many. I'm a working man, trying to make an honest living. What fucking morality you got, asshole?!! Tilley throws another egg at BB and hits him in the head again. Egg yolk drips down BB's face. He tries to get off the floor, but can't.
answer: You're the craziest human being on the face of this earth! Tilley, getting ready with another egg.

question: What else do you want from me? Huh? What else?! I've got enough problems with the I.R.S. busting my balls and the Home Improvement Commission bullshit to contend with. I don't need aggravation from you.
answer: Nobody does this to me and lives! Nobody!

question: How do ya like your eggs? Over easy? Side of tomatoes? He throws a tomato.
answer: You're going to rue the day you ran into my car. This ain't the end... this is just the beginning. Tilley throws another egg. CUT TO:

question: A guy breaks into my house and I'm being charged with assault? It makes no sense...
answer: Let's get it down right. The guy broke into your house, you hit him in the head with a gun, went to the refrigerator, took out eggs and tomatoes and threw them at him.

question: I was defending myself... he was stealing from me.
answer: It doesn't sound like defense to me.

question: I wanted to humiliate the guy. Here I am, out busting my ass all day making a decent living, I come home, and some schmuck is trying to steal from me.
answer: So you hit him with a gun, and pelted him with eggs and tomatoes?

question: If I had some soup I would have thrown soup at him... is there any law you can't throw eggs?
answer: Mr. Babowski claims he didn't break into your house.

question: What did I do? Invite him in so that I could throw eggs at him?
answer: Maybe Mr. Babowski intended to break into your house, but these circumstances of the guy being pelted with eggs and tomatoes is something we need to look into. Tilley shrugs his shoulders.

question: But I don't understand how the slate gets wiped clean when he breaks into my house and I'm the one charged.
answer: I told you, I wasn't breaking into your house. I was looking for your wife.

question: All right... all right... I'm too tired... the slate's clean... the slate's clean. The WAITRESS approaches. Couple of eggs over, some hash browns, some toast -- toasted dark... butter on the side, large grapefruit juice and some coffee. The Waitress writes his order. On second thought, instead of the eggs over, if I ordered soft boiled eggs do you take them out of the shell or leave them in the shells? We can see that BB is getting a little irritable. I don't like them that way because they get hot in the hand and it's hard to scoop the stuff out... it's not good... and you get little bits of shell in there and it doesn't taste good.
answer: Why don't you just order some scrambled eggs and be done with it... all right?

question: If I'm going to order, at least I ought to be content with my food.
answer: I'm getting a little hungry... I've got a headache as it is. Just order some eggs so some other people can have something to eat before the lunch trade comes in.

question: Why do I need a guy telling me what I should or shouldn't eat?
answer: This is not a four-star restaurant ... we're not having a gourmet meal... we're ordering breakfast, for Christ sake!

question: It so happens I haven't been to this restaurant before. I don't know how they do their eggs... if they're over easy and they're gooey, I'm not happy with it... and I'm not happy if the soft boiled eggs are left in the shell...
answer: Can I have some French toast and a cup of coffee? Bagel, what do you want?

question: Hey! I'm ordering here. At least you can have the courtesy to let a man order his breakfast.
answer: French toast and a cup of coffee.

question: Sam, this guy gets on my nerves... from day one! I knew it then and I know it now. Tilley stands up from the table and starts to leave.
answer: I'm back to pressing charges against you! Tilley turns and is face-to-face with BB.

question: You want to play that way? This game ain't over, mister... it ain't over...
answer: All right, you want to finish it now? You want to finish it right now? I'm ready... I'm ready now!

question: You're ready?! You're ready, that's what you're saying?! You're ready now?! I have to be intimidated... I have to be brought here to be intimidated...
answer: I can't stand it any longer. You're driving me out of my mind. BB lunges for Tilley across the table, Sam and Bagel try to intervene -- the Waitress doesn't know what to do.

question: So, I'm having French toast and coffee. Bagel? CUT TO: Moe, when you decided to marry May, how did you know?
answer: Know what?

question: How did ya know?
answer: You mean to make up my mind to marry her?

question: Yeah. How did ya know? This Nora is a pain in the ass, Moe... a pain in the ass. It's worse now than when she used to be around. Moe smiles. You wanna hear something? The other night at the Corral Club, I turned down a dance.
answer: You turned down a dance?

question: What's the odds on that? You think you can come up with odds on that one?
answer: Hundred to one BB don't dance... a hundred to one against. There's a beat. I'm getting out of the business, BB... I've got nothing for all this.

question: Lot of good times, Moe.
answer: A lot of good times, but I can't live off the good times. You know, my brother-in-law has offered me a job at Hess Shoes. I think maybe I should do it. You get there in the morning, you come home at night... you get health benefits... I get to be assistant manager.

question: That's it, Moe? You're gonna spend the day measuring people's feet? 'You're an "E" fit... you're a "D" wide... you got a high arch... I'll show you something in an alligator... something with a wing tip...' How can you talk about that all day long? Moe, you're the best tin man there ever was. Nobody's a better closer.
answer: It's over, BB... it's over.

question: So, May's happy about this Hess Shoe thing, heh?
answer: To say the least. CUT TO:

question: I don't want to see you anymore. She pulls away from BB and continues walking. BB walks behind her, getting soaked in the rain.
answer: I gotta talk to you.

question: I don't want to listen.
answer: Give me a chance to explain. You owe me that much. Nora still walking toward her car in the downpour.

question: I don't owe you anything. BB lets her walk away. After a beat, he yells out.
answer: It was a lousy thing to do, okay? It was a lousy thing to use you to get back at your husband... but the fact is that I never would have met you otherwise. Nora stops and turns to look at BB. It was lousy... it was a disgusting, terrible thing... but a lot of good came out of it.

question: What kind of a person would come up with such a devious thing?
answer: I'm not always a nice guy, I admit that. I got a lot of training in deceit... it's an occupational hazard. They stand looking at one another in the rain.

question: I'd like to know what it is about me that I have to fall for tin men. What kind of character flaw do I have?
answer: I didn't want to have to come here. I wish that I didn't have to ever see you again. I've gone this far in my life without having to have this kind of thing happen to me. I was going through life, sailing along, pretty good... doing okay, and I tried to get even with some crazy guy... and I'm here.

question: The wet becomes you. Gets rid of some of the slickness.
answer: I don't like the idea that I'm not in control of this, but if this stuff's got to happen, I guess I've got no choice. I wanna... ya know... ... I wanna be with ya! Okay, I said that... I said it, okay?! I wanna be with ya! It pisses the hell out of me, and I'm gonna tell you that to your face, but I want to be with you because... I miss you and I'd like to live with you... I'd like to marry you... and that's that! Nora eyes him carefully. The rain falls on her umbrella and the rain beats on BB's head. After a long moment.

question: Ya know, Tilley, we been working together for over a year.
answer: Yeah, must be about that.

question: I've been thinking that sometimes a different combination makes for better luck. Ya know what I mean? I mean, maybe the two of us ain't the right combination.
answer: I'm just getting used to ya, Sam.

question: Let's face it, we're not exactly setting the world on fire.
answer: It's a slump... it's a slump, Sam.

question: Maybe it's a slump, but like baseball, some time they have to change the lineup to get the team going again.
answer: You're not serious about this, are you, Sam?

question: Yeah.
answer: You're serious? You wanna get another partner? You don't think I'm gonna pull out of this?

question: I know you're gonna... I know you're gonna.
answer: So?

question: Look, we beat the Commission today ... you know, we got a little bit of a victory. We split right now and maybe we can add to that... you know what I'm saying?
answer: I know... I know. Change in the lineup. Okay, maybe it'll help... maybe it'll help. You got any ideas for a new partner?

question: Well, I had a conversation with Solly Shavitz, so... maybe I'll go with him. Mouse is gonna need a new partner because Dennis is going into used cars.
answer: Mouse! Mouse! He gets on my nerves... He eats too much. Here's to some pretty good times, huh? Sam smiles.

question: You're gonna come back and stay the night?
answer: I dunno... all my things are back at Nellie's -- the other side of town. I know what I could do, I'll go back to the house... there's still a few things I left behind ... at least I can get a change of clothes. They both sit down. BB looks at Nora.

question: I'm glad this is working out.
answer: You really happy?

question: Yeah.
answer: You don't really show a great deal of exuberance.

question: Honey, for me... I'm a parade. CUT TO:
answer: What happened?

question: What happened?
answer: The I.R.S... they need my furniture. They got some living room somewhere in this country that needs to be furnished.

question: They're taking the furniture?
answer: The furniture, the whole house. They locked it up... they confiscated it.

question: What do you expect? You expect to get some preferential treatment ... you're some special case? You've got to pay your taxes just like everybody else has to pay their taxes! Tilley shrugs. How many arguments did we used to have about filing your taxes?
answer: We had a lot of arguments. Nora starts toward him. Tilley sits on the steps.

question: There's a responsibility that you've got to have. It's a long way from high school, Tilley.
answer: I was doing pretty good there for a while... doing pretty good. Had my house, had a wife, a Cadillac... I still got my Cadillac.

question: Where are you gonna sleep?
answer: I'll stay at Sam's for a couple of days until I get set up. What're you doing here, anyway?

question: There's just a couple of things you didn't throw out of the house ... a couple of things I didn't find in the drawer.
answer: I don't know... I did a pretty good house cleaning number on you.

question: Listen, about the divorce. Do you want to file, or should I file?
answer: I got to be frank with you, this guy is nuts.

question: He told me all about it... all about how you threw eggs at him.
answer: He told you it was about eggs? The guy tried to break into my house. He tried to steal things from me.

answer: Hand-embroidered footstool? He walks over to his car, gets in and STARTS the ENGINE... shaking his head in disbelief. CUT TO:

question: Why are you doing this?
answer: If it's not gonna be you, it's gonna be somebody else... and if it's not tonight, it's gonna be another time. Stanley exits the office. question: If it's not gonna be you, it's gonna be somebody else... and if it's not tonight, it's gonna be another time. Stanley exits the office. answer: Maybe if I talked to him another day he'll change his mind. I mean, he's like that... one day, he's this way and another day he's that way.

answer: The bottom line is, I'm running a business, Tilley. Here's another deuce. I carried you a long time, Tilley. question: I told you, I got some business downtown. He gives her a kiss. Starts to go, turns back, gives her another kiss, more passionate this time. I'll see you later. He goes down the hall to walk out the front door.
answer: You gotta testify, huh?
